reviewText: Godzilla.  What can really be said?  We all know even without seeing the movie that this is going to be bad, but what we are probably thinking, or at least what I was thinking, was that this was going to at least have some camp value to it; like an Ed Wood movie or something like that.  Instead, I was presented with a rather boring, underdeveloped snoozefest that had me scratching my head as to any, if any, artistic merit.Akira Ifukube's score is rather beautiful.I think there is a bit of cheeky delight that comes from indulging in these monster movies of yesteryear.  I personally haven't seen too many of them, but I have seen a decent amount and, for the most part I have found them to be in the very least entertaining.  Some of them, while lacking the modernized emotional wallop (say what you will about 1933's `King Kong' being a classic, but Peter Jackson's 2005 remake is an emotional roller-coaster of epic proportions) are at least masterfully told.  At the end of the day, what we really want is to be told a good story.  I think that is where `Godzilla, King of the Monsters' falls miserably short.  It never really develops a story.  Instead, it presents us with a plot (they are not the same thing) and then leaves it at that, which leads to a barrage of boring scenes and lazily rushed together plot points that are supposed to give depth to the story.  Sadly, those points are just uninteresting.  The love triangle isn't compelling (I could care less about these people) and the protagonist is a bore.There is no meat on these bones.From a visual standpoint, I think it's safe to say that these are pretty terrible, but in a fun way.  When Godzilla comes up over the hillside I was gushing with boyish delight, despite the fact that he looked like a partially melted cat.  Still, it finally handed me the camp aspect I was waiting for; I just wish that it gave me more of that.

reviewText: This is it people! The GODZILLA we've been waiting too long to see is finally here. Thanks to the folks at Criterion, this seminal classic of Japanese sci-fi and giant monster movies is given the loving care it so justly deserves.Transferred from a 35mm fine-grain master positive taken from the original camera negative, we can now see all the pictorial splendor of Ishiro Honda's apocalyptic masterpiece fully restored on Blu-ray. This is essentially how audiences saw the film when it premiered in 1954. In addition to the original Japanese cut, we get the 1956 American version, GODZILLA, KING OF THE MONSTERS, starring Raymond Burr, which also never looked better having been taken from a 35mm fine-grain print and a 16mm dupe negative. I have to say I agree with commentator David Kalat who praises this version as being a better film than it's generally regarded. Kalat offers intelligent insights on the Japanese version's second audio track as well.The special features are sure to captivate all GODZILLA fans: Interviews with actors Akira Takarada and Haruo Nakajima, effects technicians Yoshio Irie and Eizo Kaimai, film critic Tadao Sato, and composer Akira Ifukube. There's a featurette on GODZILLA's visual effects that includes test snippets, and an audio essay on the tragedy of the fishing vessel, "Daigo Fukuryu Maru" ("Lucky Dragon V"), which inspired Honda's metaphor for atomic destruction that is GODZILLA. The original trailer, a booklet essay by J. Hoberman, and a fun pop-up storage case round up another splendid Criterion presentation of a worthy title.This is the iconic movie that kicked off Japan's enduring Giant Monster series and it's still the best one of them all. See GODZILLA the way it should be seen and love it all over again.
summary: IT'S SAYONARA TO THE CLASSIC MEDIA VERSION

reviewText: Growing up, I have seen many of the terribly dubbed Godzilla vs (insert monster's name here) spin off films.  I had not until last night seen the original Godzilla film.  I received this from my local library (thanks Washington County!).The set includes 2 discs.  The first disc contains a restored version of the original Japanese film.  This disc also contains a handful of extras.  The second disc is the American version, Godzilla King of Monsters.  There is also a booklet included with a few essays on the film.I was completely blown away by the film.  It seems that the Japanese original film was intended to convey a subtle message against war, nuclear testing, and aggression in general.  We actually see much more of the principal characters than we do of the monster.  Even in some scenes, when the characters are discussing a recent attack, they refer to it as 'the tragedy' or 'the horror' or 'the event' rather then specify 'Godzilla's attack'.  The scenes in the hospitals could be taken right from a post Hiroshima or Nagasaki post atomic bomb fallout shelter.  There is a sense of helplessness and a bit of subdued anger here, but it's portrayed in a way to not lay blame, but as a warning for future generations.The scenes actually involving Godzilla are pretty amazing.  We all can tell it's a rubber suit, and that he is smashing up models.  But it seems the filmmakers didn't really try to hide that.  It's not too campy or quirky, but it's like showing the destruction as an example.  Not special effects just for special effects sake.  I feel for the Japanese people too, because they are watching shots of Tokyo being set on fire a mere 9 years after then end of World War 2 (and the firebombing of Tokyo).  This probably stirred up some mixed emotions among the Japanese viewers.The music and sound effects are superb.  Everything works well together.  The shots (not the Godzilla dominated scenes) are very well laid out.  The black and white photography is superb.Though the story gets a bit cheesy and melodramatic at points, the story still flows rather well.  We start with a sense of suspense and pending dread with the loss of the ships out in the bay.  There is a big flurry of activity, then things seem to quiet down again just before Godzilla attacks an island.  We don't see the monster yet, but we see the after effects, including the presence of radiation.We finally see a portion of the monster while the researchers are out on the island, but he quickly vanishes and we don't see him for awhile afterwards.  At this point we really get into the back story before the next two attacks.  I can't tell you how awesomely cheesy I thought the scene with the Japanese Air Force was!  Told my girlfriend "What are they thinking trying to shoot Godzilla with holiday sparklers!?!?".  Terrific!And Criterion went one step further by including what has to be the worst Americanization of a foreign film EVER!  The American version of the film is so terrible, not even cheesy in a good way.  They added extra scenes with Raymond Burr, most of the scenes he stands around staring while we cut back to scenes from the original.  We are also treated to a pretty terrible voice over.  Also note how many times they reuse the same eight second shot of the girl (dubbed over) for when she is talking to Burr's character, and how they then switch to a shot from behind, so they can include Burr, but not really show you the replacement actress.  It's nowhere near as funny as the later cheesy dubbed Godzilla films.  Instead it's sad and horrible what was done to the brilliance of the Japanese original.  Being dubbed over with cheesy voice acting would have been fun and campy... but yeah... Raymond Burr in quick takes and narration... wow... terrible.But it's nice they included this extra, because the comparison is quite interesting.  I would say this is one of the most solid releases from Criterion in history.  They have taken a great film, restored it well (though there are some missing segments - you can tell where they are when the people seem to teleport ahead instantly), and re-mastered the audio in all of the screaming monster glory!  A solid 5 stars and a film worthy to be added to any film lovers collection.  This is a monster movie, a moving melodrama, and an anit-war and anti-nuke film all in one.  How can you go wrong?

reviewText: This Criterion Collection edition of Godzilla shows even more care taken with both versions of the film than in the Classic Media release from several years ago ( which was also pretty good ). Kudos for the extra cleanup work done to both picture and sound. It's Wonderful to have the original Japanese version as close to pristine as possible. One interesting change from the first release is that many of the subtitles for the Japanese version are different. The Classic Media edition appears to have somewhat simplified translations compared to the Criterion version. The general intent of the phrases are the same, but the exact wording is different ( "Evacuate again? I've had enough" vs. "The shelters again? That stinks." or "Damned beast." vs. "Damn it."). I suppose that different interpretations are inevitable when translations are done by different experts, but it does raise the question of which translation is closest to the original dialogue.The extras are different enough from the Classic Media release to be worth the double dip. The documentary on the "Lucky Dragon #5" incident is very informative and gives great insight into the inspiration for the film. The commentary tracks, while of neccesity covering much of the same ground as previous commentaries, still manage to include some fascinating new information about both films. The new track on the much maligned American version provides a fresh perspective on the decisions that were made regarding the re-editing ( I especially loved the tidbit about the "Gojira" vs."Godzilla" name translation debate, which should help put some of the arguments to rest). The interviews with members of the cast, crew and composer Akira Ifukube are welcome, although at times a bit tedious.All in all, this is a terrific re-issue of an often overlooked classic film. One that is too often dismissed, thanks to the juvenile reputation of the films that followed.
summary: An Even Better Presentation Than The First Release

reviewText: I see a lot of grousing about the Raymond Burr version of Gojira (Godzilla) and feel compelled to explain why it was done. In 1956 there was still much anti-Japanese sentiment in the West. After all, the West had been involved in the most devastating war in history, a war perpetrated mainly by Germany and Japan. In order to make the movie acceptable for a theater release it simply had to be recut for western audiences. While in continuity and quality the Burr version is inferior it is still a superior scifi movie of that era. It also retains a majority of the original story line. The popularity of Godzilla led to the successful release of other Japanese sci-fi movies. So, I look at Godzilla with some affection because without the success we may never have had the opportunity to complain about its inferior quality to the original Gojira. Godzilla stands up well on its own, made a ton of money and began the invasion of Japanese movies into the USA. It doesn't deserve the opprobrium.

reviewText: Godzilla is one of those iconic creatures that everyone knows, even if they've never seen a Godzilla movie: a giant radioactive reptile who likes to smash his way through Japanese cities.But for people who have only seen him fighting Mecha-Robo-Mothzilla or whatever, the original "Godzilla"/"Gojira" will probably seem like a very different movie. Despite having a man in a rubber suit squishing miniatures, this is no campiness, no silliness, no over-the-top action. It's a sobering, slow-moving movie that just happens to involve a giant nuclear lizard.Two Japanese vessels suddenly explode and sink, and the Coast Guard has no idea what or who could have done this. A single survivor washes ashore, declaring that a "monster" destroyed the boats. Oh, and fish have mysteriously vanished from the ocean, which a superstitious old guy attributes to a sea god called "Gojira."Like all superstitious old guys, he's actually right. While a group of scientists investigate the weird goings-on on the island, a vast reptilian creature appears, says hi, and then vanishes back into the ocean. He is "Gojira," aka "Godzilla," a prehistoric monster who has been woken from his aeons-long slumber by recent thermonuclear activity in the Pacific. Dr. Yamane (Takashi Shimura) is conflicted by the government's determination to destroy Godzilla.Meanwhile, Yamane's daughter Emiko (Momoko Kōchi) reveals to her new boyfriend Hideto (Akira Takarada) that her reclusive fiance, Dr. Serizawa (Akihiko Hirata) has a dark secret -- a scientific weapon that might be able to stop Godzilla. But Serizara fears it could also be turned against other human beings.People probably scoff at the idea of "Godzilla"/"Gojira" as a slow-moving metaphorical movie, but that's usually because they're either A) hung up on the rubber suit, or B) only thinking of the smash-em-up Godzilla Vs. Other Monster movies. The original movie is a far more sober affair, with more of a focus on the human characters and the struggles they go through.It's also worth noting that this movie was made a scant decade after the bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and Godzilla himself stands in for the bomb. But the metaphor has no hostility, no anger, no blame. There's just a sense of raw sorrow and pain, and a sober warning about ANYONE using the bomb. In fact, a good portion of the movie is devoted to a man who has created a horrifying superweapon, and will literally do whatever he can to MAKE SURE nobody ever can use it.Director Ishirō Honda pretty clearly knows what he's doing, littering the story with sobbing children and ordinary people freaking out. The story drags a bit when it focuses on the Emiko/Serizawa/Hideto love triangle, though -- it's at its best when it focuses on Godzilla, the havoc he wreaks, and the moral issues that crop up.Honda also gives the movie a genuinely epic scale, sweeping from a tiny fishing village to the flaming ruins of Tokyo, with people ranging from elite scientists to crusty old men who believe in sea-gods. Lots of wide shots show Godzilla smash as he lumbers through Tokyo, destroying everything in his way. Yes, it's a guy in a rubber suit, but if you can overlook that, then everything else is beautifully intense.It also has a pretty good cast -- the perpetually droopy-faced Shimura, Takarada, Kōchi, and many others. There are so many people in the movie that to describe all the good performances would take forever, since there are good ones on every level -- even extras who appear in just one scene can give amazing performances.But the most important performance here is from Akihiko Hirata. It's a little hard to get past Hirata's pirate eyepatch (why did he need that?), but he gives a raw, painful quality to Serizawa. At first he seems like an insensitive weirdo, but gradually we see that he's a man given a horrifying choice -- no matter what he does, people will die horribly. He can let Godzilla kill hundreds or thousands, or he can unleash something that could kill even more."Godzilla"/"Gojira" is a slower, deeper, wiser movie than many of the goofier sequels that came after it, and is a harrowing, intense sci-fi movie despite the rubber suit. Definitely one to see.

reviewText: What can you say about Godzilla? It was an early entry into the big monster genre that somehow stuck and created a franchise with a following that lasts till this day. It's almost beyond criticism. Almost.Here's the scoop. A smallish fishing boat off a Japanese Island gets destroyed. Other ships begin to meet the same fate and the Islanders figure it's the work of an ancient deity. No. It turns out to be Godzilla, a huge prehistoric looking monster figured to be the result of atomic testing. Forces are rallied to thwart the monster's attempt to destroy Tokyo. A weapon is devised but it in itself might be too terrible to use.This is a cool movie in that there was really nothing like it at the time. Over the years critics have called it a statement of the horror we heaped upon Japan with our use of the atomic bomb. For my dollar that's not really true. Yes this monster was supposedly spawned through atomic testing. But one of the Japanese scientists has developed an equally horrible weapon that, when push comes to shove, is used to destroy Godzilla. So they are now in the same boat as were we.It's an interesting production. Godzilla is of the rubber suit variety so they made him nocturnal to not screw up the visuals. The destruction effects are okay given the time and budget. This was shot in a narrow frame. The director had to work hard to set up shots of groups of people that looked decent. They're crowded into the frame giving it a claustrophobic feel. The story is a bit clunky. There are parts that might have been edited out so pieces of the story feel disjointed. Raymond Burr is on board to help sell to us round eyes. I heard his footage was added later but he was too well integrated into the proceedings for me to believe that.This is a fun movie. It's iconic and needs to be taken in the spirit which it was made. Enjoy it. Just don't expect too much out of it.

reviewText: At the time, the special effects were innovative. Seen as crude today, they illustrate an attention to detail, and combination of model making and video techniques that opened a new genre of science fiction cinema. The real story woven into the monster action is the message of the unknown ecological effects of nuclear tests, which were beginning to be commonplace at the time.  On the human scale, the moral turmoil of the scientist on the use and potential abuse of scientific discoveries.  The parallels to the peaceful and military use of nuclear energy is obvious.  This movie was made just ten years after Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and the Japanese sensitivity to misuse and unintended effects of nuclear science is a cornerstone of the movie.  The movie was re-cut, and scenes with Raymond Burr were added, and the movie was released in the U.S.A. as Godzilla, King of the Monsters.  It is just as enjoyable in it's own right, with Burr's character providing a narrative of the events, however some of the underlying message was watered down.  Primitive compared to contemporary movies, it has become a classic, and the moral message is as strong today as it was in 1955.
summary: More than a monster movie - a film classic

reviewText: One of my all-time favorite monster movies. Most people know this classic story, especially since the basic plot is very similar to several other 50's-era monster movies. Atomic testing in the south pacific mutates and resurrects a hibernating prehistoric dinosaur which, in turn, rises from the depths to unleash its vengeance on the nearest land mass: Japan. An eccentric scientist has created a device that might be capable of destroying the beast, but he fears his invention may be more deadly than the monster itself. Will he build the device and use it to stop Godzilla or will he destroy the blueprints? What would YOU do?As expected, Criterion treats this classic atomic age monster with the respect it so richly deserves. The master was made from the best possible film elements, but to be brutally honest, it's still not that much better looking than the Sony double-disc release of Gojira/Godzilla from a few years ago. It's a shame that someone hasn't ponied up the dough needed to do a total frame-by-frame restoration, complete with elimination of all print defects/damage. It would be terrific to have the original Japanese version AND the equally iconic American adaption looking like they'd just been filmed yesterday. Perhaps when the next generation of home video media is created (4k?) this can be done.Starring somber-voiced Raymond Burr, in one of his first heroic roles as stoic United World News reporter Steve Martin, the infamously Americanized version of the film removes 20 minutes of original footage, substituting newly-shot scenes which turn Burr into the de facto lead of the picture. It's actually cleverly done and holds up pretty well considering the rushed schedule and miniscule budget. American footage director Terry Morse cranked out a lot of product in his career, and did a good job here quickly getting all the shots needed, (allegedly filmed in anywhere from one day to  a week, depending on who you ask), to blend Burr into the Japanese footage fairly seamlessly. Burr was the PERFECT choice for the part. His voice over narration contains some of the most iconic lines ever put on film and is one of the reasons the version has gone on to become a bona fide classic of the genre. Prior to this, Burr had predominantly played heavies in film, and it was his portrayal of the doggedly determined reporter that helped him transition into 'good guy' roles and, according to Burr himself, helped him land the role with which he is most famously associated: championing TV lawyer Perry Mason.There's a reason why GOJIRA is listed by Japanese film critics as one of the top five greatest motion pictures ever made in Japan. It's unashamed anti-nuclear message is laid bare to see if you're paying attention and resonates so much more powerfully when you consider that the country which made the film had just become the first peoples on earth to survive a direct nuclear attack less than a decode before. With that said it also manages to be a gripping, rousingly intense horror-adventure film as well. This film is POWERFUL and its raw, semi-documentary style really helps underscore the seriousness of its subject matter. The U.S. version is a little more watered down, but the visuals are still strong stuff. You rarely, if ever, saw the aftermath of creature attacks in US-made monster flicks. In those movies the Hero vanquishes the monster, wins The Girl, saves the day and then stands basking in glow of triumphant victory as the final credits roll. Here in stark contrast, the nation's capitol city has been burned to the ground. Hundreds, perhaps thousands, are either dead or dying, with untold more buried beneath the scorched rubble. Even for the survivors there is no clear-cut cause for celebration, since they themselves may soon succumb to a slow, torturous death from radiation poisoning due to being too close to Godzilla during his rampage. At this film's end, only the self-sacrifice of a tortured anti-hero has narrowly wrestled victory from the jaws of defeat, while the remaining members of the cast are left to mourn the noble scientist, some saluting, some crying their eyes out. Whew! That's pretty potent stuff for a "kiddie monster movie." Those movie viewers accustomed to rapid-fire editing styles and hyper-realistic CGI effects may have a tough time sticking with the film's slow pacing and the long stretches where the title monster isn't stomping across the screen. They may also laugh at the primitive visual effects, but more's the pity for them.Personally, I love this film. It's powerful, gripping, emotionally draining at times, and great (if extremely somber) entertainment, and of course it launched one of the longest-running franchises in movie history. Godzilla himself has gone on to become one of the most widely-recognized pop culture icons on Earth. That's a pretty impressive feat for a handful of guys, (producer Tomoyuki Tanaka, director Ishiro Honda, special effects creator Eiji Tsuburaya, and composer Akira Ifukube), who took on the task of creating a movie that was based on another movie (The Beast From 20,000 Fathoms), which was based on a short story (Ray Bradbury's "The Foghorn")! The special effects techniques, for instance, that were pioneered for this film were more or less made up as they went along, yet they helped launch an entire sub-industry and F/X style (suitmation) all their own, that is still used to this day. Film composer Akira Ifukube wrote the entire powerfully iconic score for the film in less than a week, without ever having seen a single frame of the film(!) and he also created Godzilla's one-of-a-kind, instantly-recognizable signature roar. The combined efforts of these gentlemen has gone on to become one of the cornerstone films in the history of science fiction / monster movies. Easily a full 5 star film!
summary: the original is still one of the best monster movies EVER made

reviewText: For genuine movie buffs this is, indeed, an underpriced item.  It has both versions of Godzilla, plus original trailers, and quick narrated videos on writing the story, culling it into a film script, and creating its special effects.  It turns out Godzilla was greatly influenced by Harryhausen's Beast from 20,000 Fathoms, with the original Japanese proposal being for a stop-action film--but that would have taken too long to produce and been too expensive.  With a limited budget, producers opted for a man in a rubber suit and miniature buildings.  The first suit was so stiff the actor inside could barely move.  The second suit allowed movement of arms and legs, but was still so stiff it stood upright on its own when no one was inside.  It was so hot its actors periodically passed out.  Another interesting thing is that the monster was colored charcoal gray, not green.The film is often underexposed, probably to hide its lack of production values, but is still nice and clear.  The original Japanese feature is superior to the American hybrid.  At first it has a Fritz Lang-ish narration of plot-advancing cuts without Lang's expressionist moments.  As close as it comes to such a moment is a dissonant piano chord that is sounded when the heroine first sees the "oxygen destroyer" work, and which reverbs into diminishment during the next scene.  Intertwined is a melodramatic love triangle which, unfortunately, takes over and comes to dominate the action near the end of the film.  (That's a flaw in a lot of contemporary superhero films.)  And there are continuity inconsistencies to catch.  For example: why does Godzilla's booming footfalls still sound when he is underwater?  Still, for such a low price you get two quality CDs with special features and a booklet.  This is a bargain.

reviewText: It's apparent that Godzilla, the Japanese and U.S. release versions, have had a number of DVD and Blu-ray transfers, some of which have been abysmal. Beware of the reviews here as Amazon sadly lumps them all together by the film title and be certain which disc the review covers. In my opinion Criterion did an excellent job with a difficult task of restoring and transferring not one, but two films to Blu-ray, the 1954 original Japanese release, and the 1956 recut, reedited U.S. release with English dubbing and added Raymond Burr footage (shot in US). These are the best restorations and transfers yet; excellent given the condition of the film prints used. Highlights and shadows generally retain details, grayscale is even throughout and there are few flaws. Some film damage with scratches and pinholes can be occasionally seen but I believe attempting to fix what didn't get repaired in the restoration and cleaning would have done more harm than good. Audio restoration seems quite good given the poor fidelity of the original mono soundtrack. There is some audible distortion but believe it to be firmly entrenched in the original sound recording; i did not detect any obvious hiss. On the othe hand, Godzilla's roaring and foot stomping thumps sound quite good, a pleasant surprise.The Criterion Blu-ray is the best and most comprehensive Godzilla transfer to date.Criterion includes BOTH complete versions of the film - the original 1954 Japanese one released in Japan, and the recut and reedited 1956 U.S. version with Raymond Burr and English dubbing. The Japan release is the main film and the US release in its entirety is in the "supplement" section of the disc menu. Purists generally bemoan, sometimes stridently, the cutting, editing and added Raymond Burr footage in the US version, which converts the film from traditional narrative into a film noir style. The basic story is not lost, nor is some of the anti-nuke testing morality statement (albeit toned down a bit). Had the Japanese release been imported with only English subtitles - as had been done with other Japnese films, Godzilla would have come and gone quietly with distribution limited to the handful of independent Art Film theaters in major metropolitan areas. The recutting and reediting with added Raymond Burr footage and English dubbing in key places enabled the film to be much more widely distributed and enjoy substantially wider acceptance by US moviegoers. While we might cringe about it now, it was the right business decision at the time with box office success beyond wildest imagination. We can appreciate the Japanese version as the original film and concept, but should remember the US import version is what gave Godzilla its global cult status. It's also what we saw in the grindhouse theaters in their Saturday morning and matinee B-movie monster fests, and on Saturday afternoons on independent TV stations (non-network affiliates) - which is when I first saw Godzilla in the 1960's.Bear in mind this film was made in Japan just months after the massive Castle Bravo H-bomb test done by the US in the Marshall Islands - on Japan's doorstep in the Pacific - one of many - but perhaps the most notorious as the largest ever detonated by the US, above ground, with a massive 15 Megaton yield that was 3x more than its grossly underestimated 4-6 Megaton yield. As a consequence, the exclusion zone around ground zero was much too small, and fallout contamination affected the entire region with the largest radiological "accident" in US history. It also generated major diplomatic problems in the region (not just with Japan). Just like the Space Race a decade later, the Cold War was in a major H-bomb race, with the Soviets in the lead with the first practical H-bomb (deliverable weapon) by several months. This and other bomb tests spurred the many 1950's horror B-movies with monsters created by radiation exposure. Godzilla was among the first of them, and is the most famous and widely recognized - adding the "zilla" slang suffix to the English lexical - to characterize the noun it modifies as a grotesqely gargantuan monstrosity.The 1998 remake was a box office success but a critical failure. In my opinion still worth seeing (in spite of its glitzy schlockiness) but there is nothing like the cult classic original - Japan or US version, take your pick
summary: Criterion Collection Blu-ray Godzilla - FINALLY an Excellent Restoration and Transfer

reviewText: Ordinarily, the Criterion Collection offers essentially the final word on the films they release. Not so here. The earlier Classic Media 'Gojira' DVD from 2006 is better, primarily because both releases' only real extras of note are commentary tracks for both the Japanese and American versions of the movie. And Criterion's choice of David Kalat leaves much to be desired. Kalat is a bit too gushing and over-hyped and tends to basically just heap empty praise on the film. Steve Ryfle and Ed Godziszewsky did essentially the same thing on the '06 DVD, but alongside that, they offered up a wealth of detailed production information and presented it in a very professional manner.Aside from explaining why Godzilla's visual quality sucks so much even after a total cleanup (due to the type of film stock Toho used), Kalat just repeats a lot of the same stuff Ryfle and Godziszewsky did. Also he doesn't give as much information as them. It's amazing that for as fast and energetically as Kalat talks, he takes a while to get to any kind of point and overall his commentary is mostly just gushing fanboy fluff. Which is fine in and of itself. I just expected more from Criterion.My other problem with Kalat is that he seems openly spiteful of stop-motion animation artists such as Ray Harryhausen, and gets on Ray's case for complaining about Godzilla's obvious (if superficial) similarities to The Beast from 20,000 Fathoms, which came out a year prior and has been said to have inspired Godzilla's creators. He repeatedly compares the two films and usually ends up handwaving the earlier film as inconsequential or otherwise inferior. He seems to have a real bone to pick with people who did the same thing to Japanese "man-in-a-suit" monster movies - dismissing them as shoddy and inferior. But he's doing the same thing, just from the other camp, and is a massive hypocrite.So ultimately I'm disappointed Criterion's Godzilla, the supposedly only-edition-I'll-ever-need version, has such an inferior commentary track to Classic Media's from six years ago. All due respect to David Kalat who obviously loves Godzilla, but he just came across as too much of a gushing fanboy and not an actual film historian, and I feel he consequently did not take an objective look at Godzilla.

reviewText: The original, 1954 Japanese version of GODZILLA is surely my favorite monster movie ever. Maybe even my favorite movie ever. While most westerners equate Godzilla movies with hokey monsters, model cities, and bad dubbing, the original Japanese film transcends the genre that birthed it, and in its day, transformed that genre into something altogether new and different. Countless words have been written about Godzilla being a metaphor for the nuclear horror Japan experienced at the close of World War II, so I'll not belabor that point. While the U.S. version, with its added footage of Raymond Burr, retained at least a portion of the original's power, the Japanese version may be viewed through the same "serious" lens one would view Japanese classics such as SEVEN SAMURAI, RASHOMON, and IKIRU, and find it in no way wanting. Despite some crudities in its special effects, the film's grimness and documentary-style narrative imbues it with a sense of real-world horror that no other monster film, Japanese or otherwise, has ever achieved. Its limited U.S. theatrical release in the early 2000s received almost unanimous accolades from critics, and in a sense, opened a lot of eyes to a product that most American viewers only thought they knew.The intersecting stories of Emiko Yamane (Momoko Kochi), Ogata (Akira Takarada), and Dr. Serizawa (Akihiko Hirata) propel the drama, but Godzilla is the fourth character in this relationship, affecting and influencing the human characters' every decision. Emiko and Serizawa are engaged, their marriage having been arranged when they were young; however, Emiko and Ogata are in love and wish to marry, but both have deep feelings for Serizawa and have no desire to hurt him. Serizawa, in his scientific research, has discovered an unusual energy force with the power to destroy oxygen molecules, and his dilemma is whether to use it against the monster and risk it falling into the hands of politicians -- the one thing he fears more than Godzilla -- or allow Godzilla to trample Japan unimpeded. It's his sense of honor as well as his compassion for Ogata and Emiko that motivate him to make the decision he does.Tangential to the "love triangle" is the character of Dr. Yamane, Emiko's father and Japan's preeminent paleontologist, who fervently opposes the government's position that Godzilla must be destroyed, preferring that the monster be studied for its unique in its ability to survive both untold millions of years as well as massive doses of radiation from hydrogen bomb tests. Yamane is less susceptible than Serizawa to Ogata and Emiko's efforts to convince him that Godzilla must be destroyed, despite his recognition of the fact that Godzilla might inflict upon Japan a nuclear holocaust far worse than Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Only toward the end, after Tokyo has been reduced to ashes, does he appear to be reconciled to the destruction of the greatest laboratory sample the world has ever produced.The American version retains the better part of the original plot, but too much of the character development has been edited out to make room for Raymond Burr for the story to come across as more than melodrama. That's not to say the scenes with Raymond Burr, directed by Terry Morse, are totally superfluous; certainly, for American audiences of the day, relatively soon after World War II, having a recognizable American star to participate in the drama, in effect becoming the audience's eyes and ears, served to make the original Japanese story more palatable. While the added scenes are occasionally too obvious -- especially when stand-ins are used for the original Japanese actors -- they are played very straight, and oftentimes blend in surprisingly well. For all its flaws, the Americanization did allow much of the original to remain undubbed, and Burr's scenes occasionally add an additional touch of suspense, such as during the storm when Godzilla first appears on Odo Island.While most American audiences would probably never know the difference, Godzilla's rampage in the original Japanese version is far superior, in that Tokyo has been wonderfully reproduced in miniature, with Godzilla making a logical and accurate progression through the city. To Japanese audiences, the reshuffled scenes must appear quite confusing. Having Godzilla attack at night was a wise move, since the darkness adds immeasurably to the sense of menace and also offers the practical advantage of concealing flaws in the effects. Regardless, Eiji Tsuburaya's work in this film is masterful, particularly when one considers the limited budget, the time constraints, and the fact that it was all new and largely experimental at the time.Akira Ifukube scored the film and also created the ominous sound effects for Godzilla's roar and footsteps. Many of the themes that fans explicitly identify with Godzilla originated in this film, and it's all the more remarkable that Ifukube composed the score without having seen a frame of film. He was instructed to write music for "something big." I believe he succeeded beyond anyone's wildest expectations.The Criterion Collection DVD release is a true masterpiece. The Japanese and U.S. versions come on two separate discs (single Blu-Ray disc), and each film features a commentary track by noted author/film historian David Kalat. Extra features include interviews with actor Akira Takarada, Godzilla suit actor Haruo Nakajima, effects technicians Yoshio Irie and Eizo Kaimai, soundtrack composer Akira Ifukube, and film critic Tado Sato. The prints of both versions have been painstakingly restored to near-mint condition, and the soundtracks have never been more impressive. I couldn't give a higher recommendation to the presentation of these films. Some have complained about the art on the packaging, but I find it quite effective, if not spectacular. While the Criterion release is no doubt the definitive release of Godzilla, the earlier Classic Media edition at least offers several noteworthy extra features. It pays to own both.

reviewText: Criterion's much-anticipated released of Toho's classic "Godzilla" (aka "Gojira") is another important step in the film reaching its long-overdue status as a classic of international cinema.  The subtitles are good but tend to "flare" depending on the background, but the translation is very accurate although not as good as the one used during Rialto's re-realise during the film's 50th Anniversary.  The most outstading feature of the translation however is that the famous "Song of Peace" has been translated for the very first time, making this extrodinarily moving sequence even more so.Compared to earlier releases of this film, this is the best yet.  The print is generally outstanding although some scenes are better than others (for example, Toho still hasn't cleaned-up the scratchy WWII source print showing the depth-bomb pratice) but compared to Classic Images' average (and incomplete) print this is a decided improvement (oddly, although the orignial "Gojira" trailer is included, the terrific trailer for the US version was not, nor was the "Gojira" trailer restored).Even better quality is the American version, the best I've ever seen, and better still are the complete Japanese/American end credits long missing from many earlier releases of this film.But more could have been done.  While the interviews are very thorough, it's the little details that are missing: for example there is no sleeve for the booklet so it just falls out every time the case is opened.  Making matters worse is the silly Godzilla "pop-up" which tends to reinforce the "kiddy" aspect of the series; to make matters worse, the Godzilla that pops-up is not the original Godzilla!There is no "making of" documentary no a separate audio track for Akira Ifukube's stellar score.  Nor is there a still gallery of production shots, nor are there any actors or techincians bios.  A featurette on director Ishiro Honda and special effects master Eiji Tsuburaya would have been welcome.However, this is a must-have for fans of the film.  Each release gets better and this is best one yet.- Peter H. Brothers, author of "Mushroom Clouds and Mushroom Men - The Fantastic Cinema of Ishiro Honda."Mushroom Clouds and Mushroom Men: The Fantastic Cinema of Ishiro Honda
summary: A Near-Miss But A Good Try and the Best Yet!

reviewText: If you have only seen the 'Godzilla' version of this movie (with Raymond Burr badly edited into the film); then you owe it to yourself to watch the movie that the director intended. Coming as this did only 9 years after the end of WWII, the wounds of Nagasaki and Hiroshima were still raw and red in Japan's psyche...and, under the guise of being a 'monster movie', this film illustrates the way that all things radioactive had penetrated the Japanese zeitgeist, the move towards a pacifist philosophy...and, the ongoing fear that the Japanese ruling party would corrupt any new scientific inventions into weapons of war.It is somber, reflective and has a great deal to say not only about the time it was made...but, our own volatile present as well. The monster of this film is not the campy 'guy-in-a-rubber-suit' Godzilla of subsequent films...but, a scary force-of-nature that has been atomically pissed off at mankind. By limiting the monster's physical presence in the film, having the attacks come at night and making the audience's fear come from the growing anticipation of another attack, 'Gojira' tells a tale that has aged well.I highly recommend this to anyone who likes to keep their brain turned on during a movie.
summary: Sci-fi at is purest: a prism for unflinching self-examination of humanity

reviewText: If only Criterion's release were packaged as sublimely as the 2004 Classic Media release!  The earlier dual disc offering was presented absolutely perfectly.  The true-to-the-film's seriousness and ambience photo of Godzilla used on its cover (along with the red and perfectly chosen font spelling out the film's actual Japanese title - GOJIRA - along with the entire box being a nihilistic black) is a masterpiece of packaging design.  The booklet enclosed is likewise top-shelf to look at and hold - and highly informational to boot!  The menu page and chapter stops are perfect.  Unlike Criterion release's sadly silent menu/chapter stops screen, the great music of the film's composer - Akira Ifukube - plays as background while one decides where to travel to on the Classic Media DVDs. The extras are also highly informative and interesting.By contrast, Criterion's packaging of this classic film is atrocious.  The cover design in no way conveys the sombre and serious nature of the original 1954 film.  Instead it is more in tune with the many sequels of Godzilla - or more like cartoon art.  The pop-up head of Godzilla (once one opens the dual DVD case) is childish and clumsy. It isn't needed. The booklet - as others have noted - has no snug home in a fold of its own in the packaging and instead just drops out. It is annoying. The second disc has to be carefully taken as it is partially blocked by the other disc's plastic niche.  One also cannot take out the second disc without first having taken out the first one. Bad design.  The extras are for the most part very good - but a balancing with extras akin to the Classic Media release would have made for a truly delectable menu of extras.Now if only Criterion's release had been packaged as beautifully as Classic Media's!  And why? Because Criterion's transfer of the actual film is leagues ahead of Classic Media's!  Classic Media's transfer is filled with scratches and white blips and all sorts of distractions.  The image contrast is also not very good.  It was fine in 2004 when this was the best on hand back then.  But not now.  The image on Criterion's DVD is near perfect.  (I'm not writing of the Blu-ray, but of the regular DVD here.)  Also, the translated subtitles are not only more artfully presented with the image (white text against black and white image; cheap yellow in the CM version), but much of the translated dialog reads truer to what the makers of this film probably intended.So - for near-perfect packaging I recommend Classic Media's release.  For a near-perfect image and far better subtitles, you cannot go wrong with Criterion.

reviewText: This review is for the Criterion Blu-Ray DVD of Godzilla.Everyone knows who Godzilla is as he is as famous as Frank Sinatra. King Kong would easily fit between Godzilla's index finger and thumb.  Godzilla would not need to climb the Empire State building as he could bite it in half and pick his teeth with the antenna.  Godzilla is big - really big.  And this is by far the best of the Godzilla films as well as one of a handful of the best Giant Monster movies ever made.  Mostly because the movie is without humor, dead serious, dark and despairing and full of pathos, while being such an absolute spectacle that you cant take your eyes off it.This is the Godzilla movie that has the monster as metaphor for the horrors of the atomic bomb. Strangely the monster himself (as destructive and horrific as he is) still earns some empathy points because he is a dumb animal trying to survive and therefore innocent and from the right angle, his face also bares a slight resemblance to "Tickle- Me-Elmo". For the film's time in history - the special effects are pretty cool too.  Godzilla (especially the Japanese version)is a wonderful film and an unmitigated classic.I like both the original Japanese as well as the clever Raymond Burr Americanized versions for different reasons.  In both cases I was expecting a beautiful print - what, with the fancy DVD packaging, blu-ray and highly touted Criterion label.But upon seeing Criterion's films I was disappointed to find that the Americanized version looks like someone ran 50 grade sandpaper over the prints. The Japanese version fared much better but had its own problems.There are multitudes of heavy white streaks dancing about and around the Americanized version. To make matters worse this seems to occur most frequently whenever Godzilla makes a night-time appearance - when you really want to get a load of this bad boy, his face, his destructive antics and the special effects. On top of that the picture is a tad soft during these scenes, blurring the beast. The Japanese version has different problems but thankfully is in much better condition.The Japanese version is more often a rather beautiful print. Especially some of the scenes at Doctor Serizawa's house and lab or at maritime offices but at others times it seemed like your are viewing the action through a constantly moving haze. This is most noticeable when the background is almost solid grey. This is most noticeable during the jet airplane sequences. All in all the Japanese version is very acceptable and very watchable. The American version is almost unwatchable due to the defects in the film.I love Criterions work and I realize that they probably did the best they could with the material they had to work with but it is hard for me to imagine that this is the best copies of this classic film left in the world.Relatively speaking Godzilla is not that old of a film. King Kong, Bride Of Frankenstein, The Mummy and Dracula are far older and held up much better - heck there are many old silent films that are in far better condition with this American print of Godzilla.I had a hard time rating stars for this package I would like to give the Godzilla Japanese version 4 to 5 stars - but Id subtract 2 stars for the poor American print of the film.
summary: Great films - Disapointed by Criterion's Americaniszed version BluRay

reviewText: Honda's Gojira is a landmark for contemporary sci-fi drama. This film resonates to this day with the Japanese people and with audiences all around the world. One cannot view this film without seeing the anguish and torment the Japanese people endured during the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in August of 1945. Honda does well to respond and to collectively identify the Japanese people as a whole. Gojira, the monster, represents all the pain, suffering and turmoil that the Japanese people were afflicted with in the aftermath of the bombing. By showing a monster raging the city with nothing affecting him/her establishes the fear of future use of atomic/nuclear weapons. Honda does well to incorporate a sincere emotion towards the monster and towards the decision to drop the atomic bombs. In the film, the Dr. has to make the decision to use his Oxygen Destroyer or not. This is perhaps the film's most poignant illustration and response to the horrible and traumatic affects of the atomic bombs. In doing so, Honda establishes a human, intimate and deeply personal reflection. The Dr. kills himself after he kills the monster implicitly so that the instructions to make the bomb die with him and so that future scientists/countries won't ever be able to create or use the weapon again. This is a fantastic and deeply stirring film. Those who have an affinity for Japanese film, this film cannot be missed. Knowing the background of Japanese film and the inclination/obsession of Japanese filmmakers to constantly repeat the trauma their country has gone through is showcased in this film. The country finds a collective identity in this film as does the viewer. This is a great film. I would recommend viewing this film first before you endeavor to watch subsequent Gojira films...

reviewText: Like most US Godzilla fans, I've always liked Godzilla: King of the Monsters.  It's a good start to a great series.  However, seeing the original film, Gojira, was next to impossible over here until this set came out.Gojira is truly a masterpiece.  The story is a powerful one showing the (possible) dangers of atomic/nuclear bomb testing.  It's full of warnings by Dr. Yamane that this kind of testing has consequences and that it must be stopped.  It further goes to show the dangers of some scientific discoveries with Dr. Serizawa's oxygen destroyer.  And, of course, then there's the "proof" of the Yamane's warnings in the form of Godzilla.  His attack on Tokyo is absolutely stunning, especially given that it was done in 1954 and was relatively low budget.  The idea of making a less expensive monster film by putting a person in a monster suit was an untried and risky experiment, but it worked.  As much as I love stop motion animation, the movement of Godzilla is so much more natural looking.  The ending of the movie is much more chilling than the American version because it contains a warning by Dr. Yamane that Godzilla likely isn't the only member of his species still alive and that continued nuclear testing could bring about another Godzilla (which it does, in the next film.)  The story, the actors, the effects and Akira Ifukube's wonderful, dark score make for a truly fantastic movie experience.  All in all, this film is a 5/5 for me.Godzilla: King of the Monsters, sadly, is a completely different film.  It's the "watered down" version intended for American audiences.  Though, with the politics of the 1950s being what they were, and people being dragged away for suspicion of being Communists, I guess you can see why they did what they did.  They removed all of Dr. Yamane's warnings about the dangers of atomic/nuclear weapons, which does kind of make sense for producers of a film that's being released in a country that was testing and stockpiling said weapons.  They also "Americanized" the film with the addition of scenes with Raymond Burr as Steve Martin, an American journalist and "old college friend" of Dr. Serizawa.  They do get kudos for how they did that, though.  With clever editing and filming new scenes with additional characters and actors doubling the Japanese actors, they nearly seamlessly added Burr to the film.  Unfortunately, though, this adds a "buffer" between us and the story.  It's like we're observing Martin as he's observing what's going on, as opposed to the original film, where you see the action more directly as it unfolds.  Also, the "translations" for Martin's part and the dubbed English audio (for when someone's not translating for him) changed a lot of the dialog, which aided in the "watering down" of the plot.  They opted to also remove Yamane's warning at the end of the film of another Godzilla and replaced it with a "we won at great cost" speech by Martin.  (the old "happy ending" that all American films seemed to have back then)  So, while the Japanese were ready for a sequel, the American's weren't so much.  In the end, they took a Japanese masterpiece and made an above average 1950s monster movie.  This movie gets a 4/5 from me.As I said in the title, this is an awesome set and a must-have for American true Godzilla fans.  I only resisted getting it as long as I did because it comes with Godzilla: King of the Monsters, which I already had.  However, I'm glad I did finally get it because Gojira is a true masterpiece and I'm glad they finally made it available for us here in the US.

reviewText: Gojira is a film about the horrors of nuclear war. Japan was still feeling the effects, so to speak, of the nuclear strike on their country and weren't happy with a-bomb testing in the Pacific. What we have here is a giant lizard awoken by a nuclear bomb, destroying the Japanese country side with an anti-nuclear message.Also included is the American re-working, Godzilla: King of the Monsters. This one is the one starring Raymond Burr. While it isn't a faithful translation and mutes some of the anit-nuclear message, it still manages to be a decent film.Crirterion has done an amazing job with this release.Video:Being a Criterion release, you know this is a good looking transfer. There are some instances of dust, dirt and scratches, but nowhere near what we saw with Classic Media's release. The greytones are more solid and details are clear. This assessment goes for both Gojira and Godzilla: King of the Monsters.Encoded in AVC with bit rates ranging from about 15-30 Mbps. It looks very, very good.Audio:Both movies contain remastered audio (mono only for both) and are free of hiss, pops and clicks. I don't know that either film has ever sounded this good.Extras:You have Photographic Effects where the director and effects photographer go into detail behind how some of the visual effects for the film were created. 1080i full screen (both people appear in a pillar and letter boxed format, though the effects are done full screen just as the movie was filmed). About 9 minutes.Cast and Crew. These are interviews with various staff behind the film speaking about the film. There are 4 interviews total. Akira Takarada, 13 mins. Haruo Nakajima, 10 minutes. Yoshio Irie and Eizo Kaimai, 30 minutes and Akira Ifukube, 50 minutes. All but Ifukube's interviews were done in 2011. Ifukube, has, unfortunately passed away and is obviously unavailable for interviews today.Another section is call Tadao Sato. Tadao is a Japanese film critic, thus it was not included in the Cast and Crew interviews. 14 minutes.The Unluckiest Dragon, 10 minutes. This is a photo based documentary of the fishing boat that was part of what prompted the use of fishing vessels as the start of the Gojira film. The vessel in question was witness of some of the nuclear testing done in the Pacific and of course, most on the ship died or were negatively impacted by the death ash.Excellent, high quality, top notch extras. Everything was worth watching and was full of all sorts of great information.PackagingThis one comes in a nice slip cover. Inside is a really cool fold out cardboard case holding the disc. On the fold out is an awesome Godzilla pop up, similar to children's pop up books.Over all, this is a tremendous release. Many wonder why Criterion would release a film like this, but with how inbred Godzilla is in Japan's culture, and the American culture, it makes perfect sense to me. And they treated it with the respect it deserves.If you have the Classic Media Blu Ray, double dip. The extras alone make it worth it, plus now you'll have an HD edition of Godzilla: King of the Monsters, which was missing from Classic Media's release.Highly recommended.
summary: Blu Ray Review:Nothing short of amazing

reviewText: OK, so just because something is a classic, doesn't mean it's a well executed film. For the time, the effects and everything were amazing but the story is a little slow by today's standards, and even by the standards of some of the following kaiju films. There are places where it drags a bit, but overall it's a great story and well acted by the cast.That being said, the video looks great and doesn't show it's age. The audio isn't fantastic, but every sound is distinct and easy to hear. In other words, it's not 5.1 surround sound, but hey, they didn't have that back then. I would recommend this movie to anyone! You also get the hilarious Raymond Burr version of Godzilla. I watched the original and was quite moved. But then I watched the second version with him in it and it was very funny to see where they shoe-horned in all of his scenes.

reviewText: This is the ultimate home video release of Godzilla. Fans of "Big G" would be remiss to not put this edition in their film library.

reviewText: Well, this certainly exceeded my expectations.I'd asked myself "Am I being suckered here? How much clearer can a film be made when it was shot on stock which sustained permanent damage before it was even developed? When only a few years ago an exquisite restored version of both versions was released?"Well, Criterion has succeeded in working some minor miracles here. There are details, such as the matte painting of a bird's-eye-view of Godzilla's footprint, and close-ups of the puppet godzilla head, which shimmer with new clarity without looking so scrubbed and enhanced as to lose the effect of watching an OLD classic of cinema.The commentary for each version is incredibly informative and in each case has a very clear, well-chosen, well-argued. I'm able to grit my teeth to get through some cringe-inducing black-trenchcoat-geek self-indulgence in these tracks (such as the "stick it to the man" observation. I'd have taken editor's scissors to several such un-humorous asides.) because (a) the cares-way-too-much geek factor is inevitable. As a fan, I know I'd certainly make listeners cringe were I to record a commentary, and (b)the majority of the content is so well-informed, yet not at all dry or boring. I came away from listening to the commentary to GODZILLA, KING OF THE MONSTERS with a truly revised and much more educated opinion of the American version (and Raymond Burr).The rest of the extras, while not terribly impressive must-haves, are enjoyable. Especially the before-and-after examinations of the matte paintings and other photographic effects.Really, my only nit-picking criticism is that I just don't like the new cover. I'm a fan of the artist they chose, but, I find it misleading. It isn't clear enough that this is the original Toho film and not the later American Godzilla-in-name-only "blockbuster". The idea is sound, it's the execution that's unclear. However, the inner sleeve with the gorgeous Oxygen Destroyer photos makes up for that.So, in my opinion, if you're a GODZILLA fan, you should definately add this to your library.
summary: looks great, sounds great. definately worth the "upgrade".

reviewText: From a kid, "Godzilla, King of the Monsters" has always ranked near the top of my favorite films.  Until fairly recently, Americans were only privileged to see the re-done "Americanization" featuring Raymond Burr.  An outstanding film but haven't truly experienced the true story until you see the original Japanese version.  Mr. Burr does not appear and the story seems very different, with much more character development.  There is a human side to this tragedy and it comes out more clearly in its original form.  There is no cheesey comedy or cliches, but rather, a sad and sombre story of a nightmare creature who extinguishes and changes many lives.  They don't make them like this much any more and all subsequent "Godzilla" films fall far short of the classic original.  It's a thrill to have both versions together in a nice Blu Ray package. I'm so glad Criterion took this assignment as they have no equal in film restoration.
summary: Godzilla (1954)  The King of Monster Films!

reviewText: Gojira (or Godzilla as I'm sure we're all familiar with it as) was the beginning of the giant monster genre. However Gojira actually contains a cautionary tale about the effects and use of nuclear weapons, since the radioactive monster could be seen as an allegory for atomic weaponry (the images of a Tokyo reduced to rubble are haunting to this day). The monster is created by the use of nuclear weapons and spews atomic breath. It is invincible to every form of weapon and the plan that ultimately destroys it is still wrought with sacrifice. The only real knock against this movie is the acting can be a little over the top and the special effects can reduce the impact of some of the dramatic scenes (the helicopter falling over made it all too obvious it was a cheap tiny prop). Its still an incredibly enjoyable movie and I would definitely recommend it.
summary: More then it appears to be
